Scooby Doo 2 justifies the use of modern day cinema as a medium for conveying to us, the public, the difficulties of living and coping in today's world. But, it also shows us that with a little bit of self-belief and the support of others, we can achieve our ultimate goals and be accepted as an individual within society as whole.

The special effects rocked too.

For this sequence, all of the production and actors were kept, and that was very positive for this second adaptation, which this time is more grand than the previous one. This time the group that has a greater challenge when a mysterious masked man shakes the group that ends up in a disaster at a city exhibition becoming the target of criticism from the media and the population, it is up to the group to solve the mystery. Again scripted by James Gunn and directed by Raja Gosnell who evolve in history that manages to be superior to the first in practically everything including the villains who are very good different from the questionable choice of the first film, here we see several references of the animated series with famous monsters like Black Knight, Monster of 10 thousand Wolts, Bubble of Cotton, Frankenstein and Miner of 49. The cast in general is very good and the script manages to be funny and again provides a fun plot with the duo Sausage and Scooby very funny. The special effects are still weak, although they are better than the first.

Film seen on October 10, 2020.

review_title: As a scooby doo fan I enjoyed this movie
review_detailed_main: It's fun an exciting not super high quality but definitely fun and light if your a scooby fan I recommend this movie.

This is the movie that the first Scooby-Doo should have been. The characters are all back in force and the gang has never been better. It's a great film when you compare it to how the TV series episodes were done. This one involves you in the monster mystery from the very beginning and it's a suspenseful spooky ride to the very end. Not everything always goes right for Mystery Inc. but in the end the movie proves to be truer to the original than the previous movie could even attempt to do. Go to have a good time and laugh along as the gang gets chased through all sorts of mysterious encounters. Don't go looking for the next Academy Award winning picture however.

Remember the good old days when Fred wasn't an idiot, Daphne wasn't self-conscious, and Scooby always seemed to save the day? It finally happened in a live action Scooby Doo.

I didn't like the first "Live" Scooby Doo movie, the characters seemed, well, out of character, the plot was all out of whack, though the ending did improve a bit on the story, and the cut scenes on the DVD helped a little.

In Scooby Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed we have a lot of the elements that made Scooby Doo so memorable. There were music scenes, masked villains, an actual mystery, secret passages, a spooky mansion, humor and some of the lore of the multiple Scooby Doo series.

The CGI was better, and the character of Scooby seemed "more realistic" when compared to the rest of the cast. Matthew Lilliard and Linda Cardellini were still the best cast as Shaggy and Velma, however Freddie Prinze, Jr. and Sarah Michelle Gellar greatly improved upon their original performance as Fred and Daphne.

Overall, I quite enjoyed Scooby Doo 2, and if you enjoyed the original Scooby Doo cartoons, but felt cheated by the original Scooby Doo live movie, I highly recommend this one.

review_title: Scooby-Doo 2:Monsters Unleashed is very Entertaining, but does loose focus near the end
review_detailed_main: Scooby-Doo 2:Monsters Unleashed is up there with the classics, everything is very good about this film. They also added the backstory to our Characters and shared some memories. Old ones, which us Scooby fans can connect with. The film sure does have some faults but it's a good fun time. And the Villains, pretty much every single one of them turn up to seek it's revenge on the gang. Which, is very exciting. And the Villains design still holds up to this day. The best part about the film is how entertaining it is, and the pacing is very good. The story doesn't hold back and Scares, humour and some nice work between the cast who share some good chemistry and evoke on there childhood. The story is also a well told one, it relates to the early years of Scooby, and hear it's a he'll of a good time.

When it comes to deciding what movies to see, critics are the last ones you should listen too. Why? Because they are all so concerned about the construction of a film, that they no longer know how to have fun with them. This is especially true when it comes to family movies. Not every movie can be The Lion King or Finding Nemo. Nor should they be expected to be. Family movies should be one thing, and one thing alone...fun. Scooby Doo 2 delivers this and then some. I thought the first film was barely mediocre, so I had very low expectations walking in to this one. I went only because my children loved the original and were excited to see this one, and I wanted to see them have a good time. What I didn't expect was to actually like the movie myself. The sequel far outdoes the original. There are several reasons for this. First off, the cast has become comfortable with their roles. In the first movie, only Matthew Lillard appeared to be having any fun, and his dead-on performance as Shaggy proved it. Here all the remaining cast has lightened up and joined in. So the performances are good all around. Secondly, the special effects are much improved. Scooby blends in more seamlessly even though you know he's CGI. There is an incredible shot of a ghostly pirate ship emerging from behind the buildings of the dowtown city that is amazing, and very reminicent of the Stay-Puft marshmallow man from Ghostbusters. Third, as a fan of the cartoons growing up, this one looks more like true Scooby Doo. In the first movie, the monsters were not very interesting. But here, to see so many of the classic animated monsters brought to life, was a thrill. Critics have made the complaint that it's too "cartoonish". Um, hello? It's based on a cartoon! What were you expecting? The movie is also very funny, although it does rely on fart jokes one too many times. Plus anyone over the age of 5 will figure out the villian's secret identity 10 minutes into the movie. But all in all, this is exciting family fun. Family movies exist soley for families to have a good time at the movies. This is definately a good time for kids of all ages. *** out of ****.

So the usual theme been done before try to break up the team. Again Geller is Geller and Prinze Jr is just Prinze Jr. It was too obvious who the bad guy was but oh well. The music was very good, oddly. Lillard did not get on my nerves again unless i am just used to hearing him on the cartoons since he replaced Casem. What i loved was the bad guys they brought into it - Miner 49er, Tar Monster, Black Knight, yes i did like that. A few more would have been good too. Again liked Velma, liked when Shaggy and Scooby drank potions. It was a good movie, long overdue in watching, now that its what 20 years old. But yes, good one.

review_title: Scooby Doo Can Doo-Doo, But Jimmy Carter Is Smarter.

review_detailed_main: I don't get all of the hate being spewed on this site about this movie. It was fun to watch animations of Saturday mornings past come to life on the big screen. Watch those old cartoons, and I think you'd agree this was pretty good considering the subject material. It's not like they were adapting Shakespeare. Yes, its cartoony, but thats the way its supposed to be. And if Matthew Lilliard isn't Shaggy, I don't know who is. The characters seem pretty dead on, and it was awesome to see the black knight ghost come to life. Seems like I've seen that old episode at least 100 times. I don't understand the anger. Just watch it and have fun. Be a kid for two hours, its good for you.
I love it one of the best movies I've seen in a while pretty boring start but the climax is 500000000/10 i love it.

review_title: The originals are always the best
review_detailed_main: While I gave this the same rating I gave the original 2002 film, this one isn't as good as that one. Granted it is enjoyable but not as good as the original, and well you know what they say its the title of this review aswell. The originals are always the best (in most cases atleast). This movie is still funny like the first one and not as much CG as the first one which is a highlight due to there not being as much dodgy CG as there was in the original, but again it is 2004 so it's not going to be the best CGI ever. Overall this movie isn't as good as the first one but still delivers an enjoyable experience. 3.5/10.

This was not quite as good as the first film, but still worth watching.

In this film we see some super villain bringing to life various old "ghosts" from the cartoon series using a special formula that creates life out of nothing. Plot is not as great as the first Scooby Doo movie, but the acting is very good, so are the special effects and costumes. I think the idea of the past enemies of Mystery Inc all being at a party which is then crashed by Shaggy and Scooby was good and well made.

I think this film had more of a feel of being for the kids than the first film, but I enjoyed it anyway.

Yeah, I know it's not the best film in the world, and it may be very commercially driven, but it's WAY better than the first film. This is what the first film should have been, if not better. There's no Scrappy Doo ruining it for fans. There's better soundtrack songs plugged into the film.

Better character focus, although there's too many "violin scenes". There's much more nostalgia for the fans, as the original monsters are in it this time.

Fred was an appendix in the first film. This time he actually brings some entertainment and purpose with him.

Daphne's action scenes are more suited this time around, and the action has a little suspense this time.

Linda Cardellini's performance is perfect as Velma. She's the female Clark Kent.

Shaggy and Scooby have never been more buddy-buddy.

There's plenty of color and silly monsters to go around, so the kids with short attention spans will have plenty to pacify them. Check your brain at the door and enjoy.

6/10

Key talking points: . Scooby is a dog . Shaggy and Scoob have a really emotional character arc that i will not spoil here. Made me shed a tear. . Potentially the best on-screen romance between Velma and Seth Green. The chemistry was there for all to see. . Velma wears THE suit in the movie and i'm fairly confident that the scene was responsible for my growth spurt. Potentially the best film of the decade, make sure you have tissues at hand. For the emotional narrative. Not the Velma scene you dirty dog.

review_title: A Spooky Sequel Full of Fun
review_detailed_main:
Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed is a delightful continuation of the beloved franchise, offering a spooky and entertaining adventure that builds upon the charm of its predecessor. The film reunites Scooby, Shaggy, Fred, Velma, and Daphne as they confront a new mystery involving the resurrection of their most notorious foes. The plot, while formulaic, is elevated by its self-aware humor and nods to the original cartoon, creating an engaging and nostalgic experience for fans of all ages.

The cast's performances are as endearing as ever, with each actor bringing energy and charisma to their respective characters. The chemistry between the gang members feels genuine, and their camaraderie shines through in both comedic and suspenseful moments. The CGI portrayal of Scooby and the imaginative creature designs add to the film's visual appeal, enhancing the supernatural elements of the story.

Visually, the movie is a treat, with vibrant and creatively designed sets that capture the whimsical and eerie atmosphere of the Scooby-Doo universe. The special effects are well-executed, bringing the larger-than-life monsters to vivid and entertaining life. The film's pacing allows for moments of levity as well as suspense, striking a balance that keeps the audience engaged throughout the mystery.

Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed successfully expands upon the themes of friendship and teamwork, central to the franchise, while also offering a deeper exploration of the characters' personal growth and insecurities. The humor is clever and family-friendly, catering to both longtime fans and newcomers.

In conclusion, Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed is a spirited and entertaining sequel that effectively captures the spirit of the original cartoon while offering a fresh and engaging adventure. It's a fun-filled romp that celebrates the timeless appeal of Scooby and the gang, delivering a blend of humor, mystery, and heartwarming camaraderie that is sure to leave audiences of all ages with a sense of nostalgia and satisfaction.

review_title: A Silly entertaining flick based off the Cartoon show of the same name

review_detailed_main: Definitely not as good as the first scooby-doo live action movie, but still a fun mystery inc. movie. The actors are so well cast that it makes these movies so enjoyable to watch. The plot and action scenes were a shade more ridiculous in this movie, which takes away from the movie a bit. Overall, its a mindless action/comedy with a killer soundtrack.

Scooby Doo 2 is more enjoyable than the first one. I think the jokes and the special effects were even better. I liked how they took some villains from the cartoons and brought them to the big screen. That was pretty clever. After the first film which was decent, I had no intent to see this. But, I eventually gave in.

The gang is facing trouble in their town. The town is about to be taken over and they have been getting hit hard with criticism especially by this good looking TV reporter. The gang have to save their town before it's overwhelmed by evil.

The acting is okay maybe on par with the first film. Matthew Lillard as Shaggy annoyed me more in this film than he did in the first. The others I think brought up their game. Alicia Silverstone and Seth Green are welcome additions to the cast.

Overall, this is a better movie than the first. Too bad they are not making Scooby Doo 3. I rate this film 8/10.

Well, that's what it felt like to me. Seems like Scoob went down to Deadwood and picked himself up a couple of logs. A couple of logs by the name of Prinz and Gellar (aka Fred and Daphne). Talk about useless characters! This pair did nothing of any consequence in the entire film. Perhaps for Scooby Doo 3 the writers will recall that, in the end, the Scooby Doo cartoon was just Shaggy and Scooby and not all the pointless hangers on. Of course, there was Scrappy Doo and Scooby Dumb, but we won't go there.

But as for the cast, once again Matthew Lillard excelled as Shaggy and Linda Cardellini was a decent Velma. Scooby was, well Scooby, and pretty well done. In fact, the CGI for once was reasonable.

But as for the rest.....

It's a shame that the writers didn't have more imagination when they decided to "re-imagine" the Daphne character. Because all they've done is re-imagine her as Buffy and it's just retarded. So much is she that, in the future, when you're channel surfing and come across this movie you might not realize its Scooby Doo at all but think you're catching Buffy on a re-run.

As for the movie itself I guess its OK if you're a kid. But the charm of the cartoon was that the gang never faced real monsters. It was always someone in a mask. Whilst it was nice to see some of the old characters from the show being given the CGI treatment, the fact that they were now supposed to be real was a little boring.

There is some good humour fairly early on but it doesn't last long and the whole thing becomes a somewhat tedious slog to the finish which is made even more dire by the awful attempts to introduce a love interest for Velma and the whole character "development" thing pitifully attempted (and failed) for Fred and Daphne. At least the series was over in thirty minutes or so.

This sequel is neither worse nor better than the original, just more of the same. Only Shaggy and Scooby keep the film going for adult viewers and as for Gellar and Prinz......well, lets hope the writers remember why its called Scooby Doo next time.

This movie was definately not one of the best movies that I have seen but it still was an entertaining movie. First, I would like to say that whoever did the casting for Scooby Doo deserves a huge raise. He found the perfect people to play the different roles. The best fit will have to be Shaggy. This guy was born to play Shaggy. Something I still don't understand is where did Daphne (Sarah Michelle Gellar) learn how to fight with the martial arts and learn to fight with weapons. She never had that power in the cartoons, but that's Hollywood for you. Anyway, I thought this sequel was better than the first one, mostly because they didn't have a good guy (Scrappy) playing the villian and the plot was pretty good and it still had its humor. Anyway, thats about all i have to say about this movie. Overall, this was an entertaining movie.

We took our children to see this, and although it was an okay movie for my husband and self, the kids were absolutely rolling in the aisles. Our 7 year old was hysterical throughout most of the movie. We liked that it contained the monsters from the cartoons, especially one of my favorites the Black Knight. The plot was cheesy, but let's face it, aren't the cartoons the same?! Our 3 year old sat through the entire film without squirming around and this says that it truly can hold its own as far as a family film is concerned. I hate to say that one thing that disappointed me was that there was no sign of a Scooby Snack that I could tell. (I might have missed it, since I was shushing the kids.) I like the new updated looks and the fact that they are not playing Velma as being a lesbian. In fact, most will see a truly new Velma. Matt Lillard is an excellent Shaggy! All in all I will say that we were glad that we went.

review_title: One of the best kid-friendly movies of the 2000s
review_detailed_main: I watched this film so many times as a kid that I had to come here and make an effort to fix these reviews. It's hilarious, and the characters actually have character. Shaggy and scooby have some sad reflecting moments which never come up in any of the other iterations that really developed them as characters, and many of the jokes even land 15 years later. This movie deserves more credit, and James Gunn should have made more family movies because this really shows his potential which he demonstrated again with Gaurdians of the galaxy. This movie wasn't really a 10/10, realistically I'd give it an 8 or so, but these unfair reviews are not a good reflection of the quality of the movie.

I went to see "Scooby Doo 2" today with my 26 year-old sister, 60 year-old father, and a theater full of kids ranging from 6 to 13 years of age. And guess what? We ALL enjoyed it. This movie isn't "Hamlet," but it's not meant to be. Remember that it's based on a CHILDREN'S cartoon, so much of the humor is geared towards children, and the little boys sitting in front of me were having a ball!

But parent's needn't fear! The humor might be geared towards the kiddies, but with the exception of some crude toiler humor, there's nothing offensive or unpalatable to your average adult. I was laughing hysterically more than once! Everyone really kicked up their funny bones a notch for this one: Freddie Prinze, Jr was hilarious as the shaggily-coifed Freddy, and Sarah Michelle Gellar turned in another great performance as debutante Daphne. Linda Cardellini (Velma) had a very sweet romantic subplot with Seth Green's character, and Seth Green ALWAYS makes a movie ten times better than it would have been without him. Alicia Silverstone turns in a delighfully hateful performance as a spiteful entertainment reporter out to take down Mystery, Inc. And the best small part in the film comes from Peter Boyle (of "Everybody Loves Raymond"), who plays a bitter ex-rival of the Scooby gang.

I love Matthew Lillard, but I thought he overplayed Shaggy in this one, letting the character's eccentric ticks and speech patterns get in the way of many of his scenes. But when he wasn't trying to be deliberately goofy, Lillard turned in a touching performance as Shaggy and Scooby begin to doubt whether they - the perennial "screw-ups" of the team - qualify as "heroes," like the rest of the gang. And he had what was by far the best line in the entire film; it STILL has me laughing!

SHAGGY: This ties as the most terrifying day of my life!

VELMA: Ties with what?

SHAGGY: Every other freaking day of my life!

The movie was a great day out, and I wish they'd released it during the summer, because it's perfect summer fare. They gave it enough of the cartoon elements without making it unbelievable, and each of the actors were perfectly in character. And beyond all that, the movie puts across a tastefully done message that it's important to embrace who you are and love yourself for what makes you YOU. This is something that kids should NEVER stop hearing, and if they have a good time while hearing it, than all the better. I give this one a thumbs up!

PS - The second funniest scene in the entire film involves Freddy, the Black Knight Ghost, a mock-joust, and Bon Jovi's "Wanted: Dead or Alive." I won't go into detail. You've got to see it to understand. ;) LOL!
What more could you want from a movie that has such a banger ride as the Mystery Machine Limo?

review_title: This is a step down from the first film in terms of storyline and overall film but a huge step up in terms of special effects and monsters
review_detailed_main: Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed (2004) is a movie my daughter and I recently watched together on HBOMAX. The storyline involves the gang attending a crime museum opening when a villain appears and releases several of the gang historical nemesis'. Meanwhile an evil scientist has created formulas that create monsters. How does all of this tie together? This movie is directed by Raja Gosnell (Big Moma's House) and stars Freddie Prinze Jr (I Know What You Did Last Summer), Sarah Michelle Gellar (Cruel Intentions), Matthew Lillard (Scream), Linda Cardellini (Broke Back Mountain), Seth Green (Robot Chicken), Peter Boyle (Red Heat) and Alicia Silverstone (Clueless). The special effects, CGI and atmosphere of this film is absolutely perfect for the content. The storyline is okay, and the writing for the characters other than Scooby and Shaggy is pretty mediocre; however, Scooby and Shaggy are hilarious and well written and delivered. The casting is well selected and fit the characters to perfection and the attire remains well selected. Overall this is a step down from the first film in terms of storyline and overall film but a huge step up in terms of special effects and monsters. I would score this a 6.5/10 and recommend it as a fun family film.
So good,if you don't like it I won't like you. Leave a like and comment.

While it lacks the the unique charm of it's predecessor, Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed is still a great sequel that's really fun whilst also being a more traditional Scooby-Doo film. Matthew Lilllard, Sarah Michelle Gellar, Linda Cardellini and Freddy Prinze Jr. are all once again perfect and Seth Green is great. The CG is slightly better than it's predecessor but still weak. Raja Gosnell's direction is really good, it's well filmed and extremely well paced. The soundtrack is also really good and the music by David Newman is good.

This whole movie has heart, fun, and action! It goes through many character developing moments. The jokes are funny once again and the casting is great! The monsters add excitement and joy to the film. Along with the fight/action scenes. This movie is fantastic and should be watched by every Scooby doo fan!

Very underrated film which is clearly superior to the first both for screenplay and for fidelity to the original work. The casting done for the characters as for the first film is wonderful and they all play their part in a masterful way, showing themselves perfectly able to adapt the iconic characters of the animated series down to the last detail. Because what this film manages to do more than all the others of this type is to be able to maintain extreme fidelity with the spirit of the original work, managing to entertain the viewer from beginning to end and in my opinion winning the title as best adaptation of Scooby-Doo.

review_title: Childhood memorise as a scooby doo fan

review_detailed_main: The best movie ever. Even the greatest film critic ls mark knows that this film is a masterpiece.

review_title: Not as great as the first but still very good
review_detailed_main:
Im big fan of Scooby Doo and I enjoyed both movies in this film series however I feel compared to the original this lacks in few ways.

1.)I feel like this film was a little Claustrophobic. I do understand however that could be do to this movie having a lower budget compared to the first one.

2.)The jokes in this were def okay but weren't as good and felt forced at random times.

3.)The premise in the first one was alot more fun and flowed nicer. In the second I felt it was dry at times.

Overall besides this movie is def enjoyable and I personally loved it I just don't see it as massive upgrade over the first. If anything I personally feel it regressed hence why the third was cancelled.

review_title: Getting back to their cartoon roots
review_detailed_main: While checking director Raja Gosnell's (`Scooby-Doo 1 and 2') resume I learned he had been editor of the little known comedy-horror classic, Troma's 1987 `Monster in the Closet.' So before I go on, forget what you think you know about Troma films to find and rent `Monster in the Closet.'. Meanwhile, in this second `Scooby Gang' installment we find our five heroes (Freddie Prinze Jr. as Fred, Sarah Michelle Gellar as Daphne, Linda Cardellini as Velma, Matthew Lillard as Shaggy, and Scooby Do) getting back to their cartoon roots when a mysterious masked madman brings a collection of monster costumes (worn by previous Scooby-Doo cartoon bad-guys) to life to terrorize the town of Coolville, home of the Mystery Machine. Someone on the last film's production team must have read the reviews of `Scooby-Doo 1' and listened because `Scooby-Doo 2' follows the cartoon formula that gave the television series it's signature style. Back are the locations we've come to expect: an abandoned, condemned mining camp; a desolate, decaying, haunted mansion, and a spooky, foggy swamp. And, as in the cartoons, our gang needs to unmask-unmask (if you're a fan of the cartoon you understand otherwise wait to see the film) the madman behind this who-can-it-be mystery, while Shaggy and Scooby try to prove to themselves that they too are heroes. Don't expect a work of art, but do expect lots of cartoon comedy, fart jokes, whacky chase scenes, and a few lines and scenes thrown in for the adults. One of my favorites was at the opening of the museum exhibit when the Scoobys walk the red carpet. Various groupies attached to each of the heroes greets them and, of course, the group that greets Shaggy is definitely stoned. The monsters unleashed are more funny than scary, which makes this a good intro to horror for little ones. (We need to start raising the next generation of horror fans.) They even added some depth to this cast with Seth Green (Austin Powers and Buffy the Vampire Slayer) as the museum curator; Alicia Silverstone (Batman and Robin, The Baby Sitter) as the Reporter; and the great character actor, Peter Boyle as Old Man Wickles. Fans of the Scooby-Doo cartoon series will certainly enjoy this film while others will get some cheap belly laughs.

Now, I move on to the sequel to the 2002 film, SCOOBY-DOO 2: MONSTERS UNLEASHED.

I mentioned in my previous film review for the first Scooby-Doo film that the film was negatively received by critics, but was a hit with audiences and made a profit of $275 million dollars against it's $84 million dollar budget.

SCOOBY-DOO 2: MONSTERS UNLEASHED is the sequel to the first film once again directed by Raja Gosnell and written by James Gunn.

The plot shows the Mystery Inc. investigating the plans of a masked villain who wants to control the city of Coolsville using a machine to create monsters.

Unlike the first film, this film featured several of the monsters from the television series, including the Black Knight, the 10, 000 Volt Ghost, the Pterodactyl Ghost, the Miner 49er and Chickenstein.

The story is amazing and I think the writer once again successfully translated this script into a film that I enjoyed. James Gunn did a really good job with the script and Raja Gosnell directed this movie brilliantly.

The visual effects, costume and production designs are really great, especially the way they created the monsters and it was really amazing and the CGI on the monsters and Scooby-Doo is just freaking awesome.

My favorite scene is when Daphne fights the Black Knight. That was really cool, especially for Sarah Michelle Gellar, who was on Buffy the Vampire Slayer during the filming of this movie.

The acting is just incredible. The returning cast are really amazing this time around, I just wish they kept the deleted scenes in this movie and the film is just really amazing and fantastic. The music by David Newman is once again amazing. The newcomers are Seth Green, the late Peter Boyle, Tim Blake Nelson and Alicia Silverstone and they done really great performances.

The special features is really amazing in this film. You have the deleted scenes, again with and without commentary, two music videos, how the visual effects creators made Scooby-Doo dance, an insider's tool of the making of this movie and the movie-making process with Scooby-Doo, a True Ghoul Hollywood Story, two games on this film and trailers for the other movies released by Warner Bros. include THE POLAR EXPRESS and HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN and I will review those.

Overall, I give SCOOBY-DOO 2 a 9 out of 10, while the DVD's special features gets a 9 out of 10 as well.
Scooby Doo 2 of is genuinely one of my favourite films of all time and the fact that I have seen this film at least 20 times makes me upset.

review_title: Great kids movie, meant for kids.
review_detailed_main:
I couldn't care less what the reviews say about both the 2002 and 2004 live action movies. 6-7 year old me loved those movies, so late 20s year old me still love the movies. Hope were clear.

With this said I can surely understand why adults watching the movie don't find it funny or appealing, but that's the thing, it's not meant to be funny or appealing for adults. Count yourself lucky if they were giving a handful of gag that were only understandable to adults like some kids movies do nowadays, that still doesn't mean it was meant for adults. If kids love it, then it's a great kids movie. It's not that deep.

review_title: It's scooby doo as scooby doo should be
review_detailed_main:
Is this movie a technical marvel? No. Is the direction Oscar winning? No. Is it amongst the great examples of film-as-art? No. But this movie sure as hell encapsulates everything about Scooby Doo. I love this movie more than 99% of my memories from when I was of the ages 4-6 and that's only because the other 1% are memories where I watch Scooby Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed. Little did I know it, but Matthew Lillard's portrayal as Shaggy molded me into who I am today. Just kidding. I cut my hair a while back and now I look like any other white dude. But alas, I still fall engrossed with his impeccable performance upon every viewing. If I were to guess what the eternal bliss and tranquility experienced by Mormons upon their entry into the Three Kingdoms felt like, Matthew Lillard as Shaggy would be that guess. So for those of you who, like me, go and hide away from any windows whenever the Mormons coming knocking at your door because you really don't feel like talking to anyone that day, let this movie be the one true source of light in our lives. And so, I ask that, as one, we all hope and pray for Scooby Doo 3: Oh No, The Monsters Escaped From Their Enclosures!

In the name of the Shaggy, And of the Scoob, And of the Scrappy Doo,

Zoinks.

review_title: Very good film! Arguably better than the first!
review_detailed_main: Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed is a very good film that has a good cast which includes Freddie Prinze Jr., Sarah Michelle Gellar, Matthew Lillard, Linda Cardellini, Seth Green, Peter Boyle, Tim Blake Nelson, Alicia Silverstone, Neil Fanning, Pat O'Brien, and the Tazmanian Devil! The acting by all of these actors is very good. The Mystery Inc. gang are really excellent in this film. I thought that they performed good. Boyle and Silverston are very good too! The action thrills is really good and some of it is surprising. There are many hilarious scenes! The movie is filmed very good. The music is great by David Newman and great directing by Raja Gosnell!. The film is quite interesting and the movie really keeps you going until the end. This is a very good and thrilling film. If you like The the first Scooby-Doo movie and the classic cartoons, Freddie Prinze Jr., Sarah Michelle Gellar, Matthew Lillard, Linda Cardellini, Seth Green, Peter Boyle, Tim Blake Nelson, Alicia Silverstone, Neil Fanning, Pat O'Brien, the Tazmanian Devil the rest of the cast in the film, Comedy, Action, Adventure, Thrillers, Family, Fantasy, Sci-Fi, Horror, Dramas, and interesting Halloween seasonal films then I strongly recommend you to see this film today!

review_title: The gang are back in their second movie but this time it's even better.
review_detailed_main: FANTASTIC FILM.Everyones acting was fantastic, Freddie J Prince, Sarah Michelle Gellar, Linda Cardellini, Matthew Lillard and everyone else. It was a bit of a creepy film but it is very funny. I Love the Scooby Doo cartoons and I think this movie was great. The first Scooby movie was great to but this one is more like the cartoons. The Voice of Scooby Doo was fantastic because it went with the image of Scooby Doo. I love the part at the end when Shaggy is wearing a mask of a monster and Scooby Doo thinks it is a real monster. I also like the bit when the gang fights with the monsters and Scooby Doo saves everyone.I loved the film and if Scooby Doo 3 will come out it will make it even more awesome.

review_title: more entertaining than the first one
review_detailed_main:
Sure, this movie doesn't require brain power, but I found it fun and entertaining. I thought it was funner than the first one. In this one, the gang must stop a villain from bringing monsters they have captured back to real life. And Shaggy and Scooby decide they will be real detectives. I found myself laughing several times. One scene that comes to mind is when Fred is facing off against the knight and says bring it on. The knight beats him silly, and Fred says "you brought it" and falls down. Or Fred's interviews on TV. And the gang busts up Old Man Winkles meeting and come to the wrong conclusion. I even laughed at Seth Green's introduction. Velma even tries to dress sexy but ends up making some "weird" noises. Scooby searches for clues but just picks up a lot of stuff he wants. Shaggy says "those aren't clues". Funny. And I could go on and on.

FINAL VERDICT: I recommend it for anyone looking for a fun film.
A great follow up with a new Velma losing her glasses gag and shaggy and Scooby getting scared

On the very short list of movie sequels that are better than the original, you will find this movie. It is funny, sweet, and charming all at the same time. As a live action cartoon, it hits the mark perfectly. Not only was it fun to see the cartoon monsters brought to life, it was also fun to see how much the animators enjoyed giving them life. The morality tale of "always be yourself" was prevalent throughout, making for a wonderful message. Many people are overly critical of a movie like this, expecting things movies like this aren't meant to deliver. It is pure silly fun and not much more. For those unaware, the kids are blamed as things seem to go wrong in Coolsville. Determined to make things right, they track down the person behind the reappearances of old villains. Shag and Scoob trek out on their own determined to prove they can be good detectives. Down the road the gang meets up learning more about themselves along the way. Through teamwork and perseverence they (of course) get to the bottom of the mystery, unmasking the villain in classic Scooby Doo fashion. I am happy to say I had a completely enjoyable time at this movie, and was pleasantly surprised, as I hadn't expected much going in. In the wide world of moviedom, if you go in expecting Batman <The original with Adam West> instead of The Matrix, you should be in for a treat.

This movie is the greatest sequel movie and one of the greatest movie of all time. If you want to watch a movie and laugh, smile, BOLSTER OUT OF YOUR SEAT FOR, and even be brought to tears, this is the movie for you. The Two Towers is the only sequel that can be in the discussion MAYBE. If you love Scooby Doo you will love this movie.

review_title: BEST MOVIE SINCE MORBIUS 29 MORBING OF THE MORB
Monsters Unleashed: A Refreshing Turnaround for Scooby-Doo #JusticeforScrappyDoo
It's Colourful, It's Light & It's Fun!!! A Super Sequel That is Full of Stars of the late 90's to Early 2000's!!!
review_detailed_main:
Scooby-doo 2: Monsters Unleashed is a good time of a movie & one super superior sequel. This funky film is full of stars we grew up watching in the 90's & early 2000's!!!

I have alot of love for this particular Scooby-doo movie because me & one of my daughters watched this film constantly when she was little & i loved it just as much. Scooby-doo 2 is a kids film but it's also a joy for any adult that watched Scooby-doo as a kid. I've always loved Scooby-doo the cartoon & so my middle daughter got into it & loved it.

There's some great Scooby-doo films that we love, such as Camp Scare & Zombie Island & The Witches Ghost to name a few but it's Monsters Unleashed that is the best of the live-action movies.

The cast is perfect with the great Sarah Michelle Geller (Scream 2, The Grudge, I Know What You Did Last Summer) she was a big star during the 90's that i grew up watching in Buffy the Vampire Slayer & those films mentioned above. Sarah is a great actress & brought Daphne to life perfectly. Also Freddie Prinze Jr was a 90's star i grew up watching as he starred with Sarah Michelle Geller (his real life Wife) in the classic slasher "I Know What You Did Last Summer" & it's sequel, he made a decently fun Fred. Also another 90's star was Mathew Lillard from Scream &13 Ghost's & many more things & really went all out & brought the crazy Shaggy to colourful life. Lillards performance as Shaggy is excellent & the greatest performance from the whole cast!!! The girl as Velma was new to me as an actress but she was great.

The legendary Scooby-doo is brought to life with CGI & he looked great for its time in 2004. Of course CGI has advanced massively but his look is Nostalgic for me now. Great memories watching this super sequel over & over again.

There's also a little role for another 90's star, Alicia Silverstone (Clueless, Batman & Robin) as a Coolsville Reporter, this movie really now is a time capsule of its era with its then popular stars.

I love the story here about a masked villain that brings to life some of the most famous Scooby-doo monsters & how Coolsville turns against Mystery Inc.

I love the big expensive & beautifully designed sets such as Mystery Inc's HQ & the big old spooky house & the villainous bar & the museum of Mystery Inc's captured monsters. The film looks fantastic as expected for its big lavish budget. The movie is colourful & full of fun. The CGI monster are fun with some also brought to life with rubbery costumes that gave it an old school 80's feel. There's lots of silly humour that is harmless & there's a real sense of friendship fun & fantasy adventure.

Also amongst the cast is another star of the time, Seth Green (Knockaround guys, Austin Powers) as Velma's love interest.

Also the great veteran actor Peter Boyle has a small fun role.

The Mystery Machine looks beautiful.

Everything this about this film is fun & full of heart, yes it's often very cheesy because it's aimed at kids & some of the gags are abit too silly but you can't help but enjoy it all.

I have many fond memories of watching this film with my daughter & i will always have a soft spot for Scooby-doo 2 in my movie loving heart.

I loved this movie as much as I enjoyed the first one. The dizzying opening is enough to provoke headaches, but its worst criticism is that its inspired from the worst end of the Scooby spectrum - the ridiculous cartoon parody Scooby became rather than the Gothic masterpiece it was meant to be. Lillard is again excellent although Shaggy now has an identity crisis as well as selective amnesia. Thinking he's not worth anything to the team, he's forgotten he has found important clues in the past. Cardelini's presence still shines through her Velma disguise and Sara is also a gracious presence, but Prinze still falls short playing Fred as a stuck up and short-sighted playboy. Alicia Silverstone is a welcome presence even playing a "rhymes with witch" although I had would have preferred a different and much more grand end to her character. Seth Green, however, just sorts of wanders through his scenes though. I big complaint I have as I did with the first movie is that since the Scooby Gang started in the Late Sixties/Early Seventies that they would be in their Forties today. Scooby would be 259 years old (37 in people years). The plot has a lot of fake science and far-fetched magic goes into creating the ghouls from the TV series, but there's not enough images of the classic creatures. I would have preferred to see The Headless Specter, the Giggling Green Ghosts, Ebenezer Crabbe and the No-Face Zombie among others. Continuity and established facts are now out the window as the movie makes up its own history as Aggie Wilkins is now a brunette and C.L. Magnus is missing his fortune. The Miner '49 can now spew fire, but then it doesn't look the guy from the cartoon. I'm not sure if the bald thing was supposed to be the Creeper or not, and where the heck did Chickenstein and the Cotton Candy Ghost come from? Worst among the plot points is that the Pteradactyl was actually John the Caterer from "Hang In There, Scooby Doo." Who the heck is Jacobo? Well, that's creative license for you. The writers can screw up everything they want to make their movie. I just hope Scooby Doo III can live up more to the cartoon series than the first movie did.

INCREDIBLE!!!!! the best movie hands down, so much better than the first one. Scooby doo: the movie walked so that scooby doo 2 monsters unleashed can run. and i am being 100% serious no memes, genuinely one of my favourite movies i watch it every couple of months to keep it fresh in my mind, ugh its so iconic. seth green, "who's your mommy", "scooby, doobie. DOO", the soundtrack? *chefs kiss* what a brilliant film. the rating on here is WRONG!

review_title: Enjoy the movie in spite of yourself....
review_detailed_main:
Come on folks. This movie is not supposed to be rocket science. This movie was made to appeal to the kid in all of us. We are not looking for deep emotional meaning in the movie, we are looking to see if they can bring the cartoon we loved as children on to the big screen and in flesh and blood. Why can't we take this movie at face value - just enjoy it for it's campy humor and be happy in the knowledge that they have remained true to their characters and plot lines.

If you are looking for substance, you shouldn't watch a movie based on a cartoon. If you are looking for a chance to, even for just a short while, return to the innocence and happiness of your childhood - look no further.

My children enjoyed this movie for exactly what it is supposed to be. Great family entertainment.
This was a good Movie I liked a lot but yes the first one was a lot better don't get me wrong this one was enjoyable as the first one

I am ashamed to say that as much as I find the cartoons annoyingly stupid (the way they walk most of all) the film was brilliant. I must have watched it at least 20 times and the (slightly ridiculous) jokes make me laugh every time! especially 'scooby-doo, what's your conclusion?' 'BUNNY!!' The scene at 'The Faux Ghost' is great too, Scooby dancing is something I never thought I would see! It is a well known fact that the first film in a series is always the best, but in this case I think this one is better, as it contains more humour and brilliant cast members, including obsure ones. If you enjoyed the first film there is no doubt you will like this one too, if not more. The unmasking actually surprised me unlike the cartoons which may as well begin with 'WARNING!!! CONTAINS PREDICTABLE CONTENT!!!' Great for all ages.
Very good!! I loved the pursuit scenes. Mainly the characters development.

This review is going to be in line with the review I left on the first movie that came out a couple years before this one. You can't be disappointed if you watch this from the perspective of the original cartoon. It follows the humor, the running around constantly, the monsters, and most of all the heart of the show. The CGI did not improve from the first movie, but it didn't get any worse at least. The negative reviews really make me wonder if any of them are a true fan of the original cartoon. The episodes were silly but extremely enjoyable and I always looked forward to choosing which episode to watch after school. This brings nostalgia and everything I need in a live action film. Don't take it so seriously and you might actually enjoy it. It's a fun film and hits the nail on the head.
Always loved this film since I was a kid! Funny and a great cast!

There is just so much love and care put into this movie. The acting is amazing and I love how Shaggy is able to act alone but make every scene so meaningful. Anyway this movie is great. I love it. It's so good. Please watch it.
If you love Scooby doo and dumb crap then you will definitely enjoy this film

This movie was a good sequel, I couldn't stop watching this. Honestly it was a little better than the first one but The first one is still Good, It was also really cool to see the old villains return!

review_title: Not just an improvement, a significant one at that.
review_detailed_main:
Monsters Unleashed is everything I could want out of a Scooby-Doo movie. It's super entertaining, funny, has a lot of heart, and truly captures the spirit of the source material. If I have any complaints, it's that the CGI has aged pretty poorly for the most part. But regardless, it's better than the first in every other way, and is my favourite Scooby-Doo movie period.

I have to fill out the review, so I'll add a few things:

Zombie Island is a close second if you're wondering.

That potions scene is iconic. Enough said.

The tar monster looks like B. O. B. From Monsters vs. Aliens.

Your mum.

When I went to see Scooby Doo 2, I was not expecting a revolution in the film industry. I was not expecting to leave the theater emotionally jolted. I went to have fun and laugh. And I did.

This was a fun movie. Let's be honest. Nobody goes to this film to watch Fred, Daphne, or Velma. We go to watch Shaggy and Scooby. They are the ones that make us laugh. They are the ones that take our minds off the real world for a couple hours. And they did their job.

Matthew Lillard becomes Shaggy for the second time. What he is able to do in this film is incredible. You forget he is Mr. Lillard because he fully becomes the character he portrays. That is the highest compliment you can give an actor (minus a 20 million dollar check).

Scooby again is a riot. The writing allows him to remain the lovable character we grew up with as kids. He alone is worth the price of admission.

The story? Well, I have eaten swiss cheese with less holes in it than the plot. But, who really cares? I can watch The Godfather whenever I want a flawless film. But, The Godfather does not leave me in a better mood after I finish watching it, no matter how great it is. I saw this movie relax and have a good old time.

I am not ashamed to say that my wife and I went to see this together. We have no children...WE wanted to see it. And we both enjoyed it very much. It was a pleasant way to spend the evening. But don't take it from me. Take it from the dozens of small children that were in there, laughing and shrieking through the whole film. You could hear how much they were enjoying themselves. Come to think of it, that was worth the admission price in itself.

review_title: Scooby fans will be in for a treat!!!
review_detailed_main: Scooby Doo 2 is much more in depth with relationships between the characters. That is what I liked best about this film. You got to know more of them and their personality. Although this was a great movie, I still liked the first Scooby Doo better. I felt the first one was more creative and fun. I didn't like how Scooby Doo 2 ended (I won't say how) and I thought it was obvious who the villain was. I love both movies. Hopefully there will be a Scooby Doo 3. I know Linda Cardellini and Matthew Lillard are ready to sign on but Sarah Michelle Gellar and Freddie Prinze Jr. are having second thoughts. Also, Scooby Doo 2 did have better special effects. Check this movie out and you'll love it no matter what!
Ls mark told me to rate it 10 sub to ls mark please

Raja Gosnell did a much better job on this film. Although I'm slightly biased for this film (due to the fact that I watched some of the filming in Vancouver and Stanley Park) I believe this movie felt more like an episode of "Scooby-Doo Where Are You?" than the first. Characters and plot are greatly developed. This movie was especially brilliant in that the characters and story were able to be more complex all the while it stuck to it's basic roots. Monster/see the gang (exposition) - Masked figure Problem/who's to blame (rising action) - more thefts/ find monster source (climax) - destroy the source/unmask the masked figure (conclusion). The comedy (though dry on a couple jokes) was much better and unexpected at times than the first. My conclusion: Bunny.

Alrighty folks. I am true blue Scooby Doo fan. Have been since I first began watching the cartoons on televisions (thank you re-runs). And when I heard that Cooby was coming to the big screen. I was so for this project. The first film was freaking hilarious, and new that the second was going to topple that one, and boy did it. More laughs, more scares, and more Doo. The whole plot was unique, and was totally fabulous to watch. I was laughing so bad that I was in tears. The whole 70's Dancing Scooby, I thought I was going to pee my pants from laughing so hard. This movie is the one to watch. It kept true to the old cartoon. I wished they added some more Ghosts from the original series. Oh well there is always Scooby Doo 3.

Much, much better than the 1st attempt to bring Scooby Doo to the big screen. Though, if you read my review for the first film, you will see I give it a good review. Which at the time was very accurate. However, after having seen the second film - I wish I would have not been so liberal on the review.

I truly did enjoy this film much more! It had the look and feel of the old cartoon. The characters seemed more cartoonish, the plot, the sets, etc.

This could very well have been the first film, if not tweaked slightly. This one blows the first out of the water.

My daughter loves it and that's all that matters to me. She watches this movie as well as the first one over and over. Slight adult sense of humor for the grown-ups watching the continuous kid loop. Scooby Doo connoisseur's also commend it's true representation of the cartoon. From what I remember they're right. Mysteries are on par with original episodes with a nice spice of originality. Movie is well filmed using bright colors and appealing personalities. All actors and actresses do a wonderful job of playing the characters, emulating voices and overall presence. The two that really stand out are Matthew Lillard and Linda Cardellini, they are outstanding! The others are good too, but Matthew and Linda really bring it home!

I'm really reviewing for my son who is 9. The movie has great chase scenes, funny moments and good music. You should see him playing the air guitar to the music and running along with Scooby and Shaggy. He just loves this movie. Very slapstick.

From an adult perspective, I appreciate the slapstick as well. While the story may be formulaic, I still like the results. I am still amazed at the match the studio was able to get between the live action actors and the cartoons/voices from the originals cartoons. I also appreciated the Buffy links through Alicia Silverstone, Sarah Michelle Geller, and Seth Green. 7 stars from my view.

Nice little escape film. Better than the cartoon. Seth Green dragged it a little but wasn't too much a detriment. Visual gags are clever and well-executed. Don't take it too seriously. A hot Velma always works with me. Daphne is cute too. Scooby animation is better than the best cartoon work. It is Scooby antics that help sell this film. Since this is based on a cartoon, don't over-analyze the plot holes, just willingly suspend your disbelief. It made $83 million in the box office. A moderate success, IMO. Lillard saying the box office was disappointing and that's why there will be no Scooby 3 doesn't seem true to me.

First of all,Scooby Doo 2 was great and one of the funniest movie. Because, the graphics and effects were awesome in this movie.Also,the actors did a great job on making the movie similar to the animated version. Next, the characters were funny and cheerful just like in the cartoon shows especially Scooby Doo and Shaggy. Third, Vilma,Fred and Daphne were interesting and very serious about their investigations on each case they faced. Overall Scooby Doo 2 was fantastic and surprising since you'll never know who the real monster/bad guy is until the conclusion of the movie.

In conclusion, I gave Scooby Doo 2 a 10/10. Thanks to the actors,directors and performers who helped this movie to become possible.Plus, the Mystery Machine vehicle looks authentic and pretty much the same as the ones in the animated shows of Scooby Doo.

In addition,it was fun to watch over and over again and without a doubt you wouldn't get bored while watching it.

it is a laugh out loud movie for the whole family it is a fantastic movie it has some great songs on it like Wanted Dead Or Alive by Bon Jovi it is a great movie it is a two thumbs up movie you and your family will like this wonderful movie a lot it is a hoot i have never seen a movie quite like this before it really is a laugh out loud this movie is hilarious it is one of the best movies ever made it is a big hit i never saw anything like this in my life you will say cool it is a laugh out loud movie for the whole family will enjoy i know so it is a great family movie i never saw a movie like this in my life it is one of the best Scooby Doo movie you just have to see this masterpiece of a wonderful movie this movie is outstanding you will like this movie a lot i never saw a movie like this in my whole life you just have to watch this wonderful movie that i call a masterpiece this movie should be back out in theaters but in RealD 3D and IMAX 3D now that would be cool have a fabulous day everyone

review_title: Scooby's Back, And So Are Some Real Monsters!
review_detailed_main: I enjoyed the original "Scooby-Doo," and was looking forward to the sequel, "Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed." However, I didn't enjoy the second movie as much as the first. I thought the theme of unmasking, i.e., pretending to be something one isn't, was a bit overdone. But still, the movie had its good points. I found the visual effects well done. And the use of villains from previous "Scooby-Doo" cartoon episodes, such as the Black Knight and Captain Cutlass, shows great potential. I admire that the movie adheres to the spirit of the cartoon this way. To true Scooby-Doo fans, "Monsters Unleashed" might be a disappointment, but not a complete one!

review_title: Ours is the dream life and sleeping is what's real
review_detailed_main: Not a sad movie but attached to a larger more imposing sadness. It's a very watchable movie for me but for sad reasons. It is as though the movie serves as a constant reminder that failure is the most natural thing in the world. Like if you graph it, the line goes up for a bit and then it starts to go down and continues going down until the line is finished.

Well I was excited about getting to see this film being a big fan of Scooby Doo. I liked the first one but it lacked alot of the Scooby elements, with this sequel, I felt like I was watching an actual Scooby Doo cartoon episode with them running around creepy mansions and a town with monsters on the loose. It was also wonderful getting to see some of their old villains come back and I really liked how they played that up. I agree with what was said in an early user's comment about it getting bad reviews because of the people who are reviewing it, they're basically looking for Oscar nominations not the fun side of things. I usually tend to enjoy the movies thatget bad reviews the most. I was proud of Sarah Michelle Gellar, she wasnt as annoying as she was in the first. One problem I would have to say I had with them film was there were too many sappy moments where they had to give each other pep talks and tell each other that they are worth something or they'll mope around feeling sorry for themselves, some if it is good to have but it seems they broke off from the action to include one of these scenes. As a whole, I really liked this movie and I was laughing more then I did in the first one.
Gotta admit, this sequel is good! It could've been better. 8/10 to me!

review_title: Mysteries and monsters, that's what Scooby Doo 2 is all about
review_detailed_main:
I have just returned from having seen Scooby Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed in a packed theatre, not a single seat left empty. Families with kids from toddler to teen populated the dark interior. There were some moments during the movie when I cringed, expecting to hear the frightened shrieks of the younger, more sensitive members of the audience but was relieved to hear not one single cry, not even when the sound effects got loud, not even when I jumped a couple of times at the unexpected.

The quick (and correct) plot summary is: Mystery, Inc. has donated costumes to the Coolsonian Criminology Museum. These costumes were worn by the various schemers and crooks over the years that Mystery, Inc. has unmasked when solving assorted mysteries. Someone has devised a way of creating real monsters by using these costumes and a substance called randomonium and that same someone is determined to completely destroy Mystery, Inc. and Coolsville with these new monsters.

There were some really cool moments in this movie, the Pterodactyl ghost flying away with the Evil Masked Figure was pretty awesome, Shaggy and Scooby playing with chemical potions was very funny, Seth Green is very funny as the museum curator. There are the pre-requisite fart jokes but they are funnier than what was in the first Scooby Doo movie, the theatre laughed hard at one scene involving Miner 49er during his unfortunate encounter with Shaggy and a nervously gassy Scooby. In fact, most everything about Scooby Doo 2 is better, funnier, cleaner and smarter than the first one. There were a few scenes that felt a little clumsy, Fred being masculine, Daphne being Buffy-ish and Scooby dancing makes three. For some reason the Black Knight Ghost was given a lot of dialogue, unfortunately you can't understand a single word except his last sentence, which happens to be a bad pun. The other ghosts are mostly, and appropriately, monosyllabic, as were their cartoon forerunners.

The special effects are seamless right from the beginning, the Pterodactyl-eye view of Vancouver, BC as Coolsville is stunning. The shimmer effects with the ghosts is very cool, the bright and vibrant colors lend to the completely fantastical vision of this fantastically fictional place inhabited by the most normal looking oddballs one could imagine. This time around, Matthew Lillard, (there is no better Shaggy), gets to play more with Scooby. Linda Cardellini still has the Velma vibe going and Neil Fanning is the Scooby voice master. Sadly, Freddie Prinze, Jr. and Sarah Michelle Gellar still do not understand who Fred and Daphne are or what they are about. It's distracting to see preppie Fred turned into a valley/skaterboy and I do not remember Daphne being so vapid and self-involved. Peter Boyle makes a perfect Old Man Wickles, cranky and completely bothered by the very existence of Mystery, Inc., Tim Blake Nelson in his brief appearances as Jacobo looks completely crazed. Alicia Silverstone was adept as a TV reporter who apparently has a bit of a grudge against Daphne. That leaves the stars of this movie, the monsters, most of which are CGI and voiced by experienced voice actors in the usual cartoon manner, but four of the ghosts are actually humans inside elaborate costumes. They did an excellent job of acting through the layers of prosthetic makeup, costuming and physical absence of their CGI screen mates. The added effects of glowing randomonium and varying degrees of transparency combined with complete obedience to their leader, the Evil Masked Figure, made the danger to the inhabitants of Coolsville apparent.

The sets, costumes, music, sound effects, visual effects, it all works to transfer the small-screen cartoon to the big screen in live action. For Game Boy Advance players, stay until after the very last name in the credits has rolled to see what Scooby Doo has just for you.

review_title: Better Than It Needs To Be!
review_detailed_main: This movie is so much better than it needs to be. What we have is a 90 minute episode of Scooby-Doo. Unlike it's dismal predecessor, this movie does a great job of capturing the look and feel of the original cartoon, while simultaneously bringing it into the real world. Be a kid at heart, relax & enjoy some zonked-out monster madness!

Scooby Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed (2004)-

The fact that Daphne is now a full on "Part Buffy" fighting ace is one of the best bits for me, because I always liked her and because we all knew that she could be kick-ass if she was given the chance.

What is also great is that this sequel didn't try too hard to beat its predecessor and ultimately ruin itself.

It's a shame that other people didn't feel that way, because the second sequel was shelved (Later turned in to a cartoon).

I could quite easily have watched dozens of Scooby-Doo films with this dynamic and awesome cast and more of the fun scripts that they were gifted in the first two though. Box office numbers be damned I say!

Once again all of the lead actors give performances that are true to character and I love the interactions that they have with the supporting cast too.

This time they face a whole host of spooks and have to prove themselves to be the cool dudes that they are as their reputation is put on the line.

It's got the same silly humour and camaraderie as the first and it would probably score as high as that one if it wasn't repeating some of the jokes (They still work though) and didn't cheapen it by bringing in Big Brovaz, a band that disappeared as quickly as they came.

I'm sure I'll get stick from the 22 year old uber-fan nephew, but I'm not saying that it's bad at all. I love it and will watch it again and again.

795.71/1000.

review_title: This is more fun than the first! REALLY CORNY!!!
review_detailed_main:
Although Shaggy(Matthew Lillard), and Scooby hogged all the attention, this movie haven't lost its touch. Fred and Daphne(Freddy Prinze, Jr. and Sarah Michelle Gellar) were closer than the first. Velma(Linda Cardellini) was still the brains behind the group, yet the most insecure of the group as well. She seems to work well with Shag and Scoob rather than Fred and Daph. Shaggy and Scooby are always the cowardly of the group, yet they never realize how well they're good at finding clues that the others don't.

This movie is also more musical than it was in the first one. It was sure a howl when Scooby had on that afro. He was really FUNNY! Unfortunately, he really gave out that term "wigging out". Velma didn't lose her glasses that much in this movie. I think she is hot, with and without her glasses, and when i saw her with those leather pants and heels. She made a real stiff out of herself. I mean she was completely awkward.

Battling most of the creatures past made a big difference in this sequel. And seeing the past criminals was also interesting as well. And all this time, the gang were tailing the wrong man throughout the movie, and Heather(Alicia Silverstone) was a shady character as well, trying to smear the Mystery Inc. gang. Shame on you! Although she was fake.

The music number was flawless, Ruben Studdard of "American Idol" do the old Earth, Wind,& Fire's "Shining Star" which everyone really put on a show. And I think it what makes this movie better than the first. I think its time to start bashing the critics about the movie, it's one of my favorite cartoons, and I'll enjoy it from time to time. But I hope there's no chance for a third one. If there is one, make sure no one hogs the screen light like Lillard did! Rating 2.5 out of 5 stars!

Scooby Doo 2 is well written, directed, edited and acted, the movie is a lot of fun and James Gunn makes a great character piece of the gang, the soul of Hanna Barbera's Scooby Doo is here and it's exploited to a maximum level, it's a cinematographic expirience that plays with tropes you know and it is better in every single way than the original

Now, I move on to the sequel to the 2002 film, SCOOBY-DOO 2: MONSTERS UNLEASHED.

I mentioned in my previous film review for the first Scooby-Doo film that the film was negatively received by critics, but was a hit with audiences and made a profit of $275 million dollars against it's $84 million dollar budget.

SCOOBY-DOO 2: MONSTERS UNLEASHED is the sequel to the first film once again directed by Raja Gosnell and written by James Gunn.

The plot shows the Mystery Inc. investigating the plans of a masked villain who wants to control the city of Coolsville using a machine to create monsters.

Unlike the first film, this film featured several of the monsters from the television series, including the Black Knight, the 10, 000 Volt Ghost, the Pterodactyl Ghost, the Miner 49er and Chickenstein.

The story is amazing and I think the writer once again successfully translated this script into a film that I enjoyed. James Gunn did a really good job with the script and Raja Gosnell directed this movie brilliantly.

The visual effects, costume and production designs are really great, especially the way they created the monsters and it was really amazing and the CGI on the monsters and Scooby-Doo is just freaking awesome.

My favorite scene is when Daphne fights the Black Knight. That was really cool, especially for Sarah Michelle Gellar, who was on Buffy the Vampire Slayer during the filming of this movie.

The acting is just incredible. The returning cast are really amazing this time around, I just wish they kept the deleted scenes in this movie and the film is just really amazing and fantastic. The music by David Newman is once again amazing. The newcomers are Seth Green, the late Peter Boyle, Tim Blake Nelson and Alicia Silverstone and they done really great performances.

The special features is really amazing in this film. You have the deleted scenes, again with and without commentary, two music videos, how the visual effects creators made Scooby-Doo dance, an insider's tool of the making of this movie and the movie-making process with Scooby-Doo, a True Ghoul Hollywood Story, two games on this film and trailers for the other movies released by Warner Bros. include THE POLAR EXPRESS and HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN and I will review those.

Overall, I give SCOOBY-DOO 2 a 9 out of 10, while the DVD's special features gets a 9 out of 10 as well.

my sons are huge scooby fans, we must own every scooby-doo movie. we took them to the first movie and they loved it and laughed, when it came out on video we had to buy. when they heard that scooby-doo 2 was out they just had to see it. once again they laughed their heads off and after the movie my middle son asked if we could buy it. i personal thought it wasn't quite as good as the first but i enjoyed it very much. shaggy and scooby make this movie, if they were the only two in the movie it would still be number one. but when you add the other characters to the movie it's a great combination. if you want to take your kids to any movie this year, make sure it's this one. one thing i find as a plus is that there is no foul language, which is great for kids. so if your kids loved scooby-doo 1 they will adore scooby-doo 2. now when does it come out on video so my kids can watch it over and over again, until i'm sick to death of it.

review_title: Even Better Than The First One
review_detailed_main:
If you enjoyed the first one, then you'll love the second one even better!

Sarah Michelle Gellar fighting scenes are spectacular! Daphne can kick some major monster butt! I just love her!

Fred was okay. I like his new hair cut. Velma is hilarious! I Love the scenes with her and Patrick.

As for Shaggy, well where to start? This guy was also freaking hilarious. Matthew Lillard brings Shaggy into real life! His the most believable Scooby Doo character in the movie. His so gosh darn cute, and I swear I love that Shaggy voice. Oh and the part where Scooby and Shaggy ate some dangerous chemicals! Well I won't spoil you, but it was funny as heck.

Overall this movie was fantastic! If you have a kid it's a must see! If you don't it's still a must see movie!

Having grown up watching the cartoon, I was disappointed in the original. But this is more like the cartoon and alot better than the first one. I mean, what do you expect? It's a live action cartoon, keep that in mind. This isn't suppose to be social commentary or a "change the world for the better" movie. It's about a group of Ghost busters and their dog. If you have kids and find the cartoon entertaining, then this is a great movie to see. If your looking for something other that just good entertainment then go watch something else. I was very disappointed in reviews that blasted the movie. This will be one movie I look forward to seeing again on DVD.

Wow, I really enjoyed this movie. From the first scooby doo, I thought this second release wasn't going to be as great, but I was wrong. This is one of those movies that keep the views on thier feet. It was a great movie to bring my nephew too, he really enjoyed it as a kid. But I found myself enjoying something a little different, fun and entertaining. I didn't remember seeing Alicia Silverstone in the first one, but that could just be me. I think the cast was great too, they are all the uprising stars you see in movies here and there. Good show, something different and very fun! I'd recommend taking all the little ones or even for something different. Two thumbs up, nice work!

review_title: Elements of interest to many groups
review_detailed_main:
Some people may turn their noses up at this one. Another sequel designed to squeeze out another couple of dollars for the franchise. To a degree that may be true (hey, nothing wrong with making a buck!).

That said, this film still contains some items of interest. For the kids, great show, very funny and enjoyable. For those who grew up with the animated series, you will love it. Very true to the original cartoon series with a lot of the same type features and plot devices. For those who are a fan of the "animated actor" (I think we can start to use that phrase now to differentiate a character from just a special effect, I mean, what would the LOTR films be without the input of Golum) there are some great scenes of interaction.

Another thing to note is that this film is not simply a remake of the first film (as a lot of sequels are), this very much stands on it's own feet. However, I do think that this really should be the last feature film we see of the Scooby characters, I honestly don't think a third one will sustain the momentum that well.

Overall - **1/2 stars

review_title: So much better than the first (sorry) attempt...
review_detailed_main: I am a "Scooby Doo" fanatic!! No one was more excited about the live action version back in 2002 than me (although I was looking forward to a Scarborough-esque retelling when Mike Myers was still attached to the project (complete with a Barenaked Ladies cover of the second greatest theme song in television history!!)). I, a 30+ year-old woman, much to the chagrin and delight of my friends/work colleagues, even had a "Scooby Doo" countdown. I bought my nieces and friends (forced to accompany me to what was sure to be the film event of a generation) Scooby-Doo merchandise. Nothing could ruin this moment for me, until I actually saw the film! Needless to say that my utter disappointment in their first attempt (Shaggy is a vegetarian...hello what about all of those salami sandwiches he and Scooby ate in the cartoons!!) didn't put me in a state of readiness for the second offering but my love of that wacky Great Dane and the promise of the superb Seth Green did make me want to see Number 2...a little bit. Well, this time I was not disappointed! They actually got it right this time!! A tribute rather than a joke at the expensive of long time (and yes over 30!) fans and only one fart joke (and not a bad one at that!)! It was great to see all the old monsters creatively redone in CGI! The cast was excellent (ok, it's not Shakespeare but they did a great job with the fantastic, pure camp that they had and it was good, old-fashioned fun camp this time too!). And yes, Seth Green was amazing as ever (psycho, cute, and lovable all wrapped up in one neat little package!) So, go and see SD2, especially if you didn't like the first one. If you're anything like me (and heaven help you if you are!) you'll like it...a lot!!!
